1831 Faraday publishes his principles of induction by electromagnetism, generation, and transmission
Ada Lovelace Byron publishes her analysis of Babbage’s ideas and lays the foundations for computer programming theory
George Boole publishes his mathematical ideas, which will form the basis for Boolean algebra. 1878 Edison Electric Light Company is founded

note: Thomas Edison introduces his incandescent lamp.
title: The first commercial lighting system is installed in Cleveland, Ohio; it uses arc lighting
The first hydroelectric power station opens in Wisconsin

William Stanley introduces an alternating current (AC) electric system, and the work of Frank Sprague develops the technology to use a transformer system to make long-distance AC transmission possible. The Westinghouse Electric Company is founded. 1888 Nikola Tesla invents the rotating field AC alternator

Tesla addresses the Franklin institute in Philadelphia and explains the theory of radio communication. Westinghouse demonstrates an electricity generation and transmission system at Chicago’s World Exposition
Guglielmo Marconi develops the first practical radio system
The electron is described by J
John Ambrose Fleming invents the thermionic valve, the first radio tube diode
Robert von Lieben and Lee De Forest develop the amplifier tube, the triode
De Forest invents the vacuum tube electric amplifier, the­ Audion
Ewin Armstrong introduces the regenerative feedback amplifier and oscillator
The first news program is broadcast on radio in Detroit
Entertainment broadcast radio is launched in England
Philo Farnsworth presents the first public demonstration of electronic television

Claude Shannon publishes his paper laying the basis for the application of binary numbers to switches in electronic circuits, which becomes the basis of digital circuit design
Bell Labs demonstrates the Complex Number Calculator, which is able to perform calculations over the telephone line
Konrad Zuse creates the Z3 computer in Berlin

container-title: It is used by the Allied forces to decrypt Nazi war communications
title: in a 1943 bombing raid. The Bombe computer is developed from a Polish design by the British

John von Neumann outlines the structure of a stored-program computer, the Electronic Discrete Variable Automatic Computer (ED-VAC). It introduces the ideas for the binary system and leads the way for digital computing

note: Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer (ENIAC) is developed at the University of Pennsylvania.
title: William Shockley, John Bardeen, and Walter Brattain of Bell Labs invent the transistor
Freddie William and his colleagues invent the Random Access Storage Device

container-title: It is the realization of the EDVAC idea
title: Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator (EDSAC) is introduced at Cambridge University. It uses subroutines stored on punched paper tapes and thus is the first practical stored-program computer

note: The Standards Eastern Automatic Computer (SEAC) is the first to use all-diode logic.
title: Engineering Research Associates sells its ERA 1101 (the first commercially produced computer) to the U.S
The National Bureau of Standards constructs two large computers (the SEAC and the SWAC) to test components
Another early commercial computer, the Ferranti Mark 1, is released. The UNIVAC I built by Remington Rand is sold to the U.S
International Business Machines (IBM) releases its model 701, the first electronic computer
Texas Instruments sells the first consumer transistor radio, the Regency TR1. IBM releases the IBM 650 magnetic drum calculator, the first mass-produced computer
